filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Songs of Innocence Copy G, from the Yale Center for British Art, and Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copy N, from the Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
Innocence Copy G was printed with fifteen others in the book’s first printing in 1789. Four of these copies were later joined with Experience impressions, printed in 1794, to form Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies B, C, E, which are in the Archive, and D. Copy G also joins Innocence Copies B and U and will be joined in the coming years by eleven more separately printed copies of Innocence that are currently in production. Unlike many of these early copies of Innocence, Copy G still consists of all 31 plates originally composed and executed for Innocence. The plates were printed in yellow ochre ink on 17 leaves and wiped of their plate borders; the designs were very lightly washed in watercolors and the texts left unwashed. These borderless designs, printed on both sides of the leaves to create facing pages, look more like illuminated manuscripts than prints or paintings. This mode of presentation exemplifies Blake's early printing and coloring style. Using the Archive’s Compare feature, which enables users to juxtapose impressions from the same illuminated plate printed in different periods, users of the Archive can contrast this early style to Blake’s late style, c. 1818-1827. For example, in Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies V, Y, Z, and AA, which are in the Archive, Blake printed and finished the impressions to look like miniature paintings.
After 1794, the printing history of Innocence becomes complex because Blake began printing it with Experience to form copies of the combined Songs while continuing also to issue Songs of Innocence and Songs of Experience separately. Complicating matters further are the facts that some separately issued copies of Innocence were combined with Experience by collectors and dealers, and that copies of Innocence now separate were once part of copies of the combined Songs. Copy N of Songs of Innocence and of Experience contains 25 plates, all from Songs of Experience. These are numbered by Blake 30 to 54, thus indicating that the copy once included Songs of Innocence. This may have been what is now called Copy W of Songs of Innocence, untraced since 1941. The Experience impressions of Songs Copy N were printed with plate borders in brownish-black ink on one side of the leaf and finished in water color washes and pen and ink outlining. This is an intermediate printing and coloring style, between the earliest styles as represented by Innocence Copy G and the color printed works of 1794 and late style, c. 1818-1827.
Like all the illuminated books in the Archive, the texts and images of Innocence Copy G and Experience of Songs Copy N are fully searchable and are supported by our Virtual Lightbox and ImageSizer applications. In addition to the Archive's Compare feature, users can use the Lightbox to juxtapose and examine images from any of the works in the Archive side by side, as well as crop, zoom, and juxtapose them for close study.
New protocols for transcriptions, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to Innocence Copy G and Experience of Songs Copy N and to all the Innocence and Songs texts previously published. With the publication of these two copies, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 83 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, color printed drawings, tempera paintings, and water color drawings.

objinfo.pennednumbers: 30-54The numbers written by Blake in pen and ink appear top right on each print. This sequence of numbers indicates that Blake numbered, and probably issued, this copy of *Songs of Experience* as part of a combined copy of *Songs of Innocence and of Experience*, with the general title page and the "Innocence" plates numbered 1-29. These "Innocence" plates may have been what is now called Copy W of *Songs of Innocence*, untraced since 1941. For discussion, see Joseph Viscomi, *Blake and the Idea of the Book* (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1993) 297.

desc.objtitle: SONGS of EXPERIENCE, Object 1 (Bentley 29, Erdman 29, Keynes 29)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a composition dominated by strict verticals and horizontals, a young curly-haired male (behind) and young gowned female (in front) with her hair pulled back in a bun bend over two dead(?) bodies, an old, bearded, gowned(?) male (in front) and a gowned(?) female (behind), who are laid out on a draped table (possibly a bier) that extends from the left to right edge of the design. The two mourners are seen in profile facing left, their heads looking down toward the bodies, and holding their hands to their heads in gestures of distress, perhaps crying or in prayer. The corpses are arranged with their heads resting on pillows at left. The visible (right) arm of the male is at his side. These two figures may be tomb effigies. In the background is a paneled wall or partition flanked by pilasters—a cemetery wall, tomb, or church interior; on the right pilaster appears the ostensible date of publication, "1794" (line 5). A triangular shadow covers part of the floor or ground beneath the young woman's feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Despite the strong, quite inorganic block capital letters, the letters of the first word of the title have ornamental extensions. The initial "S" (line 2) sprouts a vine-like extension from its top, a cluster of flowers or tendrils with leaves that extend across the first three letters; from the bottom of the "S" another tendril, with one loop, terminates in a flower or leaf. An extension from the top of the "G" divides left into leafy or thorny branches, to the right into a pair of flowers or leaves. The top of the final "S" sends out a tendril with many small loops that curves right and down below the letter nearly touching the head of the floating figure. The "of" has two extensions with several branches and leaves, probably ivy. Three human figures are associated with the text of the title. Standing on an extension at the bottom of the initial "S" is a gowned figure with arm raised. Two figures flank "of" (line 3): to the left (facing right) hovers a gowned female with long hair that streams behind her in a kind of tail, her arm extended, and to the right (facing left) hovers a nude male, his left arm raised and his left leg extended backward, as if leaping in mid-air. Blue washes suggest sky, upper right and between "SONGS" and "EXPERIENCE".

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by a cloud in a night sky with scattered stars. The text appears on the cloud. Below the text, on the bottom of the same cloud, a nude female with long hair reclines on her left side on a cloud-like couch that terminates at her feet in serpentine drapery. And weeping in the evening dew:

lg.l: And her locks cover'd with grey despair.
Starry Jealousy does keep my den
I hear the father of the ancient men
The virgins of youth and morning bear.

That free Love with bondage bound.

lg.l: Love seeketh not Itself to please.
Nor for itself hath any care;
But for another gives its ease.
And builds a Heaven in Hells despair,
So sung a little Clod of Clay.
But a Pebble of the brook.
Love seeketh only Self to please,
To bind another to Its delight;
Joys in anothers loss of ease,
And builds a Hell in Heavens despite.

lg.l: A little black thing among the snow:
Crying weep, weep, in notes of woe!
Where are thy father & mother? say?
They are both gone up to the church to pray.
Because I was happy upon the heath,
And smil'd among the winters snow:
They clothed me in the clothes of death.
And taught me to sing the notes of woe.
And because I am happy. & dance & sing.
They think they have done me no injury;
And are gone to praise God & his Priest & King
Who make up a heaven of our misery.

lg.l: I was angry with my friend:
I told my wrath, my wrath did end.
I was angry with my foe:
I told it not. my wrath did grow.
And I waterd it in fears,
And I sunned it with smiles,
And it grew both day and night,
Till it bore an apple bright.
And my foe beheld it shine,
And he knew that it was mine.
When the night had veild the pole;
In the morning glad I see;
My foe outstretchd beneath the tree.

Into the dangerous world I leapt:
Like a fiend hid in a cloud.
Bound and weary I thought best
To sulk upon my mothers breast.

lg.l: In the forests of the night:
In what distant deeps or skies.
Burnt the fire of thine eyes?
On what wings dare he aspire?
What the hand, dare sieze the fire?
Could twist the sinews of thy heart?
And when thy heart began to beat.
What dread hand? & what dread feet?
What the hammer? what the chain,
In what furnace was thy brain?
What the anvil? what dread grasp.
When the stars threw down their spears
And water'd heaven with their tears:
Did he smile his work to see?
Did he who made the Lamb make thee?

lg.l: A flower was offerd to me;
Such a flower as May never bore.
But I said I've a Pretty Rose-tree.
And I passed the sweet flower o'er.
Then I went to my Pretty Rose-tree:
To tend her by day and by night.
But my Rose turnd away with jealousy:
And her thorns were my only delight.
Who countest the steps of the Sun:
Seeking after that sweet golden clime.
Where the travellers journey is done.
Where the Youth pined away with desire,
And the pale Virgin shrouded in snow:
Arise from their graves and aspire.
Where my Sun-flower wishes to go.
The modest Rose puts forth a thorn:
The humble Sheep, a threatning horn:
While the Lilly white. shall in Love delight,

Or any of my brothers more?
I love you like the little bird
That picks up crumbs around the door.
The Priest sat by and heard the child.
In trembling zeal he siez'd his hair:
He led him by his little coat;
And all admir'd the Priestly care.

Your spring & your day. are wasted in play
And your winter and night in disguise.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are three boys playing a game of marbles on a bare patch of ground, but with grass below. To the right of the boys is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children, nude (bottom figure) or in tights: (bottom to top) one—long-haired and thus perhaps a girl—standing with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin is another elaborate vine with a large bird perched near its top, left of the first stanza. There would appear to be a figure standing in this vine, left of the fourth stanza. The tinting of the text area suggests the sky at sunrise (see "summer morn," line 3).

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy in tights on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game of marbles that he and the other children present are playing.

The short-haired (perhaps curly-haired) boy in tights in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. His left leg is bent under him; his right leg is extended to the left. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left who is poised to shoot a marble.

The right-most child—apparently male—in the group below the text has long hair and wears tights. He is sitting, bending sharply forward with head and arms down. Though facing left, he appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired (and nude?) girl or boy stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg. Its arms fuse with the plant.

A short-haired boy in tights climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing right, he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.

A child in tights, probably a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide, and he appears to wear shoes.
Facing right, a child (probably male), wearing tights, sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. He holds, and appears to be reading, a book.
The figure sitting at the top of the vines on the right appears to be reading an open book.
A figure wearing a gown stands in the vine left of the fourth stanza. She(?) faces forward, with her head turned to the right.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation—perhaps grass—and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and at least one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 21.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 8(?). An intertwined vine climbs the tree, with one loop left of the fifth stanza.
The green tinting on the ground just above the lower margin of the plate suggests grass.
The tinting of the text area suggests the sky at sunrise (see "summer morn," line 3).
Three children play a game of marbles. Three marbles are visible on the ground beneath the right-most child.

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
The little ones spend the day.
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour.
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
How shall the summer arise in joy.
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
When the blasts of winter appear.
